stem: The nurse is caring for a patient with a history of COPD who is admitted for acute respiratory distress. Based on the provided data, categorize the patient's acid-base imbalances at each time point.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
07:00 SBAR: Patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of COPD, admitted for increasing shortness of breath. He reports increased sputum production and difficulty breathing for the past 3 days. Home medications include albuterol inhaler PRN and tiotropium inhaler daily. 

07:15 Assessment reveals patient is using accessory muscles to breathe. Oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. He is alert and oriented but appears anxious. Auscultation reveals diffuse wheezing and diminished breath sounds bilaterally. 

07:30 Albuterol nebulizer treatment initiated. Oxygen initiated via nasal cannula at 2 L/min. Continuous SpO2 monitoring in place. 

08:00 Patient reports slight improvement in breathing. Oxygen saturation now 92% on 2L/min. Repeat assessment reveals decreased wheezing. 

09:00 Patient reports feeling more comfortable. Oxygen saturation 94% on 2L/min. ABG drawn for analysis. Will update provider with results.

tabs.content:

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
07:15: Patient appears anxious, using accessory muscles to breathe. Diffuse wheezing and diminished breath sounds bilaterally. 

08:00: Wheezing decreased. 

09:00: Breath sounds improved, less labored breathing.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
• Administer albuterol nebulizer treatment every 2 hours PRN for wheezing.
  • Administer oxygen via nasal cannula at 2 L/min, titrate to maintain SpO2 > 90%.
  • Monitor respiratory status and vital signs every hour.
  • Draw ABG if respiratory status worsens.

rationale.correct: At 07:30, the pH is 7.30 (low), PaCO2 is 60 mmHg (high), and HCO3 is 26 mEq/L (normal). This indicates uncompensated respiratory acidosis. At 09:00, the pH is 7.38 (low normal), PaCO2 is 55 mmHg (high), and HCO3 is 28 mEq/L (high). This suggests compensated respiratory acidosis, as the HCO3 is elevated to partially compensate for the elevated PaCO2.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect selections indicate a misunderstanding of ABG interpretation, compensation mechanisms, or the primary disturbance versus the compensatory response.

answerBreakdown.rationale: At 07:30, the pH is 7.30 (acidic), PaCO2 is 60 mmHg (elevated), and HCO3 is 26 mEq/L (normal). This indicates respiratory acidosis because the primary disturbance is an elevated PaCO2 causing the acidosis. The HCO3 is within normal limits, indicating no metabolic compensation.

At 09:00, the pH is 7.38 (slightly acidic), PaCO2 is 55 mmHg (elevated), and HCO3 is 28 mEq/L (elevated). This suggests compensated respiratory acidosis. The elevated PaCO2 indicates a respiratory issue, and the elevated HCO3 indicates the kidneys are retaining bicarbonate to compensate for the acidosis.

clinicalPearls: In COPD patients, chronic hypercapnia (elevated PaCO2) is common, and the body compensates by retaining bicarbonate. It's crucial to assess the pH to determine if the acidosis is acute or compensated.
Always evaluate the patient's clinical presentation alongside the ABG results. For example, improved oxygenation and decreased work of breathing can influence the interpretation of subsequent ABGs.

questionTrap.trap: Confusing compensated respiratory acidosis with metabolic alkalosis due to elevated HCO3. Students may focus solely on the bicarbonate level without considering the PaCO2 and pH.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Emphasize analyzing all three values (pH, PaCO2, and HCO3) together and understanding the relationship between them. Use the ROME method (Respiratory Opposite, Metabolic Equal) to aid in identification.

mnemonic.title: ROME
mnemonic.expansion: Respiratory Opposite, Metabolic Equal. Respiratory Acidosis/Alkalosis: pH and PaCO2 move in opposite directions. Metabolic Acidosis/Alkalosis: pH and HCO3 move in the same direction.
